author: Jen Mills For Metro.Co.Uk
title: BA baggage handlers 'corroded planes by urinating on them' | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Tuesday 21 Feb 2017 8:58 am It allegedly affected some of the fleet of 747s (Picture: Getty) 
British Airways baggage handlers have reportedly been told to stop urinating in the cargo hold of planes as it damaged the metal. 
Some workers were allegedly relieving themselves in the hold because they didn’t want to walk all the way back to the terminal. 
But staff were warned that they should stop this after engineers discovered flaking metalwork, The Sun reports . 
Urine is corrosive to aluminium, the metal which is used to construct 747s. 
There is no suggestion that planes were put in danger by people urinating, but the warning was reportedly given to prevent any future damage to the fuselage. It was ‘too far to walk to the terminal’ (Picture: Rex) 
In 2004, a bridge in Indonesia became unstable and was in danger of collapsing due to the frequency of people weeing on the steel pillars holding it up. 
A source told the Sun: ‘It can be a real trek back to the toilet facilities at the staff centre and when you have to go you have to go. 
‘Eventually it emerged urine is quite corrosive and there was some issues with some of the Boeing 747s.’ 
‘No plane was in any danger but staff were told to stop and use the proper facilities.’ 
A spokesman for the airline told the paper that they had no record of any such warning being given. 
Metro has contacted BA for comment. More
